title: Jonny Wilkinson says England are a more 'complete' side than his 2003 World Cup winners
text:
Jonny Wilkinson thinks Eddie Jones’ England are a more complete side than his 2003 World Cup heroes.

While the side from 16 years ago are so revered in the nation’s sporting psyche, the icon from that team believes Owen Farrell’s side are playing on a different level.

Having watched the way England dismantled the back-to-back world champion All Blacks Wilkinson was mightily impressed.

Jonny Wilkinson thinks England are a more complete side than his 2003 World Cup heroes

And while he admitted it was tough to compare eras, he has been stunned by the speed of thought and deed of the 2019 crew.

‘England have this incredible make-up of individuals which is geared to play professional sport at the highest level,’ said Wilkinson.

‘And I think we had it as well.

‘If you had all our guys and sent them back to their mid-twenties and then threw them into that squad and said - “let’s compete” - I think you’d find something very similar because of the internal make-up.

‘When you compare the external stuff, the skills and the speed, then yeah, it’s a different game.

England secured a stunning 19-7 victory over New Zealand in the World Cup semi-finals

‘Did we ever play that quick, did we ever play like that? We never really knew how to. We played the game as we saw it.

‘We challenged our barriers where they were. I think the barriers have moved a long way. These guys, it’s a new generation, they’re quicker, they’re faster, stronger.

‘Everyone’s more complete. Whatever number is on your back you’re able to do everything.

‘It’s like – “you’re a prop”. “And?” “You’re a winger”. “Yeah, well, fine”.

‘I look at these guys and every position, they’re challenging stereotypes.’

And Wilkinson is proud of the fact that his 2003 team will have inspired the senior men in Jones’ squad.

Wilkinson's (top left) side from 16 years ago are revered in the nation’s sporting psyche

‘What we did in 2003 opened the door for people younger – at the age of 11 or 12 like Owen Farrell and George Ford – to go “wow, these guys can pass left to right hand,”’ said Wilkinson, speaking on behalf of Land Rover, Official Worldwide Partner of Rugby World Cup 2019.

‘You have got props looking at Phil Vickery thinking: “Jeez, he gets around the field”. Suddenly by the age of 21 you have got incredible players.

‘Players are going to get better and that's good because it is as a result of what we are doing. They are not better than us, they are better because of us. That's the beautiful thing.’

While Wilkinson himself felt caught up in the search for tangible success he sees this side as one who can go on to achieve greater things.

‘This is a stepping stone for these guys whether they like it or not,’ said the former fly-half, now 40 years old.

Wilkinson kicked the winning drop goal to give England victory in extra time in Sydney

‘At the age of 21 you can see some of them being like: “Well I've won the World Cup, I'll retire now.”

‘It's a stepping stone. Life gets better. Not measured up against lifting up a World Cup, it gets better because you get to perform again.

‘And also you speak to guys like Lawrence Dallaglio and the other guys – Martin Johnson – I don't think he was thinking: “I just need to get through this game”.

‘Those guys just loved battling. They loved it. They would have done it for another two hours in that game.

‘I got the impression that most of our team wanted Elton Flatley to kick that last goal in extra-time in 2003 because they were thinking: “we don't want to win because your guy missed, we want to win because we win it.”

The England legend thinks the current crop of players are superior in terms of skill and speed

‘I got the impression those guys were excited. “Let's get in there, we can go win it again.”

‘For me I was a little bit caught up in the reputation thing.’

But he feels Farrell and Co will not be bogged down by the most important week of their lives.

‘They’ll have the same press days, the same training sessions,’ he explained.

‘Maybe several more faces appearing at those press days, maybe more white shirts appearing around the hotel. That’s the bit that looks different.

‘Nothing to do with what the England team are doing. It’s more how they managed that side of it.

Wilkinson doesn't think England will be bogged down by the most important week of their lives

‘As you get nearer the end you get excited about arriving, and that’s the danger because you start to feel – “get me there”.

‘The arriving is a recognition of reward, and I feel that’s the danger in a World Cup.

‘You’re getting closer. On a vulnerable day in the World Cup finals I was involved in - if you’d got to me with a piece of paper that said “you can win this but you don’t get to play,” I’d have signed that.

‘I just feel like they are en route so much more than I was.’

Land Rover is Official Worldwide Partner of Rugby World Cup 2019. With over 20 years of heritage supporting rugby at all levels, Land Rover is celebrating what makes rugby, rugby. #LandRoverRugby
description: WILL KELLEHER IN TOKYO: While the side from 16 years ago are so revered in the nation's sporting psyche, the icon from that team believes Owen Farrell's side are playing on a different level.
authors: Will Kelleher For The Daily Mail
